title: How to Improve Your Photography Skills Using Personal Photographic Assignments

steps.headline: Pick a weekend and only use one lens.
steps.description: No matter what, just that one lens. Make it work. If it's a zoom, pick a focal length and stick with it. You will learn that focal length and a lot more about composition. (If you can't do it for the weekend, try it for a day).

steps.headline: Spend a whole day taking photographs with just a single aperture.
steps.description: It will help, considerably, to use Aperture Value or Aperture Priority (or whatever they call it).

steps.headline: Do the same as above, but apply it to shutter speed (S or Tv...).
Take a weekend, or even a week and shoot only manual.
steps.description: Stay completely out of any of the programmed modes.

steps.headline: Do the same as above, but manually focus.
steps.description: (You might want to make sure your vision is good or your diopter is set correctly.)

steps.headline: Switch up the camera.
steps.description: If you have a backup, or one that you don't use often, use it. (This is really only helpful if you also shoot with film).

steps.headline: Pick a 'rule' and stay with it.
steps.description:
Some rules are:
Rule of Thirds
Balancing Elements
Leading Lines
Symmetry and Patterns
Viewpoint
Background
Depth
Framing
Cropping

steps.headline: Explore various techniques with your camera and do only them for a while.
steps.description: Get some practice in. Something like panning or freezing action, etc.

steps.headline: Choose a type or setup of lighting and stick with it.
steps.description: Practice using it with various subjects and angles.

steps.headline: Reproduce others' works.
steps.description: No, not copyright violation, but try to reproduce the effect they accomplished in the photograph.

text:
Pick a weekend and only use one lens. No matter what, just that one lens. Make it work. If it's a zoom, pick a focal length and stick with it. You will learn that focal length and a lot more about composition. (If you can't do it for the weekend, try it for a day). Spend a whole day taking photographs with just a single aperture. It will help, considerably, to use Aperture Value or Aperture Priority (or whatever they call it). Do the same as above, but apply it to shutter speed (S or Tv...).  Take a weekend, or even a week and shoot only manual. Stay completely out of any of the programmed modes. Do the same as above, but manually focus. (You might want to make sure your vision is good or your diopter is set correctly.) Switch up the camera. If you have a backup, or one that you don't use often, use it. (This is really only helpful if you also shoot with film). Pick a 'rule' and stay with it. Some rules are:
Rule of Thirds
Balancing Elements
Leading Lines
Symmetry and Patterns
Viewpoint
Background
Depth
Framing
Cropping Explore various techniques with your camera and do only them for a while. Get some practice in. Something like panning or freezing action, etc. Choose a type or setup of lighting and stick with it. Practice using it with various subjects and angles. Reproduce others' works. No, not copyright violation, but try to reproduce the effect they accomplished in the photograph.
